question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the generated code is executable for display. Please help me create a 3D model in HTML format showing the Li₆PS₅Cl crystal lattice with co-doping of Cl and Br elements, and indicate the migration pathways of various ions.

checklist.title: Is the 3D crystal lattice structure of Li₆PS₅Cl accurately implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code correctly represents the Li₆PS₅Cl crystal structure with proper atom positions, bond lengths, and lattice parameters according to crystallographic data. Check if the code uses the correct space group (F-43m) and includes all atomic positions for Li, P, S, and Cl atoms. Score 0 if the structure is completely inaccurate, 5 if basic structure is present but with significant errors, and 10 if the structure matches published crystallographic data with high accuracy.

checklist.title: Is the co-doping of Cl and Br elements properly visualized?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code implements the substitutional doping of Br at Cl sites with appropriate visualization (distinct colors, sizes, or labels). The implementation should show the distribution of dopants either randomly or at specific sites based on energetic considerations. Deduct 5 points if only one halogen element is shown, 3 points if the doping is visually indistinguishable, and 2 points if the doping ratio is unrealistic. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are the ion migration pathways clearly visualized?
checklist.description: Check whether the code effectively visualizes Li+ ion migration pathways through the crystal structure, showing the energy landscape and bottlenecks. The visualization should distinguish between different pathway types (intra-cage vs. inter-cage transitions) and indicate energy barriers. Deduct 5 points if pathways are static only, 5 points if energy barriers are not indicated, and 3 points if the coordination environment changes during migration are not shown. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the implementation use appropriate 3D rendering techniques?
checklist.description: Evaluate the 3D rendering implementation using WebGL (Three.js, Babylon.js) or similar technologies. The rendering should include proper lighting, camera controls, perspective, material properties, and anti-aliasing. Deduct 3 points for missing camera controls, 3 points for improper lighting that obscures structural details, 2 points for lack of material differentiation between elements, and 2 points for missing anti-aliasing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as browser compatibility issues, WebGL not supported, performance on low-end devices, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or fallback mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the scientific visualization experience (e.g., 1. Interactive property calculations 2. Real-time manipulation of doping concentration 3. Energy barrier visualization along migration paths 4. Cross-sectional view capabilities). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar visualization methods 2. Function modules unrelated to crystal structure visualization (e.g., unnecessary UI elements) 3. Effects that affect performance without adding scientific value (e.g., excessive particles or animations). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core visualization functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating crystal structure data/rendering/interaction layers), performance optimization techniques, and code maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 3 points if the code doesn't implement memory management for large structures; deduct 2 points if the render loop isn't optimized for performance. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional scientific visualization standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the visualization follows scientific standards: 1) Appropriate color scheme for different elements (following CPK or similar convention) 2) Proper scale representation with measurement indicators 3) Clean interface with scientific annotations and legends. Deduct 3 points for incorrect atom coloring, 3 points for missing scale indicators, and 4 points for lack of proper legends explaining visual elements. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the interactive experience intuitive and educational?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactive features enhance understanding: 1) Responsive rotation, zoom, and pan controls 2) Interactive selection of specific atoms or pathways 3) Visual feedback when examining structures 4) Educational tooltips or information panels. Deduct 3 points for sluggish controls, 2 points for missing selection capabilities, 3 points for lack of educational content, and 2 points for unintuitive UI elements. The full score is 10 points.
